threat: A local attacker could exploit this to read portions of kernel stack memory, leading to a loss of privacy.
A local attacker in a Xen guest could cause the Xen host to use all available CPU resources, leading to a denial of service.
If a remote attacker were able to acquire a socket lock, they could send specially crafted traffic that would crash the system, leading to a denial of service.
A local attacker could determine the memory layout of processes in an attempt to increase the chances of a successful memory corruption exploit.
A local attacker with physical access could plug in a specially crafted block device to read kernel memory, leading to a loss of privacy.
A local attacker with physical access could plug in a specially crafted block device to crash the system, leading to a denial of service.
A local attacker with access to the video subsystem could exploit this to crash the system, leading to a denial of service, or possibly gain root privileges.
A local attacker with access to the video subsystem could exploit this to run the system out of memory, leading to a denial of service.
